title: No Taxation Without Representation
subtitle: The Stamp Act Crisis (1765)
narrator: William, age 16, apprentice to a Boston printer, 1765

sections.title: The Stamp Act
sections.summary: My name is William, and I am sixteen years old. I'm an apprentice at a printing shop in Boston, learning the trade from Master Green. Today, March 22, 1765, news arrived that has everyone in our shop furious: Parliament has passed the Stamp Act.

sections.title: Sons of Liberty
sections.summary: A group calling themselves the Sons of Liberty has formed to resist the Stamp Act. They meet at night, make plans, and intimidate anyone who supports the tax. Their leader is Samuel Adams, a firebrand who writes passionate articles against British tyranny.

sections.title: Colonial Unity
sections.summary: In October, representatives from nine colonies met in New York for a Stamp Act Congress. This is remarkable—the colonies rarely cooperate. But this threat has brought us together.

sections.title: The Townshend Acts
sections.summary: Our celebration didn't last long. In 1767, Parliament passed new taxes called the Townshend Acts, named for Charles Townshend, the British Chancellor of the Exchequer. These taxes are different from the Stamp Act—they're duties on imported goods like tea, glass, lead, paint, and paper.

sections.title: The Power of Resistance
sections.summary: These years have taught me something profound: ordinary people have power when they stand together. vocabulary.definition: A 1765 British law requiring colonists to pay a tax on printed materials by purchasing special stamped paper.
The colonial principle that they could only be taxed by legislatures where they had elected representatives, not by Parliament.
A colonial organization that used protests, intimidation, and sometimes violence to resist British policies like the Stamp Act.
A Boston leader and organizer of colonial resistance against British taxation and policies.
A 1765 meeting of representatives from nine colonies to coordinate opposition to the Stamp Act and assert colonial rights.
Refusing to buy certain goods as a form of protest. Colonists boycotted British goods to resist unfair taxes.
